text: when popovers are made correctly they
have a delicious golden-brown crust on
the outside and a light airy texture on
the inside and today I'm going to show
you how to make perfect popovers
to start I'm going to need three eggs
now the most important ingredient here
in making popovers is steam and steam
comes from a lot of different liquids in
the batter so three eggs to start this
process off and I'm going to whisk the
eggs together with one and a half cups
of the whole milk now I have all of my
ingredients at room temperature and you
want to make sure that your batter in
the end is at room temperature so it
will help to develop the steam so whisk
these two ingredients together until
they're nice and frothy you want to
incorporate a little bit of air here and
that takes about one minute so my egg
and milk mixture is nice and frothy
these bubbles in the end will help
create the rise of the popover to this
I'm going to add one and a half cups of
all-purpose flour and of course salt
very important one and a quarter
teaspoons of coarse salt so whisk this
together until it's combined but there
can be a few lumps you don't need to
over mix the batter that will toughen up
your popovers so you're looking for the
consistency of heavy cream maybe a few
lumps and popovers they're of the same
family as Yorkshire pudding their
English cousin also Dutch baby pancakes
they're one of those nice delicious eggy
batters okay so this is ready to go it's
about the consistency of heavy cream
with a few lumps in it if you wanted to
flavour your batter in any way adding
some spice maybe some herbs you could do
that at this time so I have a popover
pan preheating in my oven I'm gonna go
grab that
so my popover pan has been in the oven
preheating at 425 degrees I have it on a
sheet tray and the sheet tray actually
helps to conduct heat which will
encourage
the popovers to rise even more I'm using
a little bit of nonstick cooking spray
spray each of the cups liberally take
your batter and you want to fill each
cup up 3/4 of the way with the batter
and this room-temperature batter in
these hot cups will immediately start to
cook you can almost hear them and this
whole rising process all of that steam
that's going to be generated is going to
create such nice lofty popovers so 3/4
of the way full right back into that 450
degree oven you're going to bake them
for 20 minutes and then you're going to
reduce the temperature down to 350 and
bake for another 20 until they've pumped
up over the pan and they're dry to the
touch and of course golden-brown and
delicious so the popovers look great
they've actually popped over the cups
here now what you want to do is remove
them immediately to a wire rack and a
little trick in maintaining the shape is
to take a small paring knife and you
want to create a little slit in the
popovers and this helps to release any
steam and what it will do is it'll help
preserve the shape a little bit longer
so you don't have to rush to get them to
the table however I don't think you're
going to want to wait because these are
the most delicious popovers now serve
them with some butter maybe some jam and
there you go guys look at the interior
is nice and light and airy and there it
is
popover perfection enjoy
you
